introduction.p: Sound is a mechanical wave that is responsible for the sensory experience of hearing. We can hear a sound wave in air if its frequency lies between 20\text{ Hz} and 20\text{ kHz}. This range of frequencies is called the audible range. Sound waves of frequencies above 20\text{ kHz} are called ultrasound, and those below 20\text{ Hz} the infrasound.

At the source, sound waves are generated by vibrating objects, such as the vocal chord, a guitar string, membrane of a drum, spaker, etc., and propagate through a medium, most commonly air, from one location to another. Sound is also detected by sound vibrating a membrane, e.g., in the ear drum and in microphone. Since sound is a mechanical wave, it has all the properties of mechanical waves we have described in a previous chapter.
